page.title: 17Development of Oakley
page.content: Oakley's oldest building is St. Mary's Church. This, and older farmhouses, cottages and barns are built of limestone (oolitic) with tile or thatch roofs. In time, the village has moved away from the church and river. Growth was slow. The most notable C19 buildings were erected by the Duke of Bedford. Inter-war development was slow with land bounded by High Street, Church Lane, Lovell and Station Roads remaining largely farmland. Field names remain in the street names of the new estates - Dewlands, Ruffs Furze, Lincroft - which consist of C2O styles and materials - brick and tile, with much glass and white woodwork (or plastic) in evidence - which have little in common with traditional materials of North Bedfordshire.
